reference_textbooks: Management Information Systems: Managing the Digital Firm by Laudon & Laudon
course_description: Study of information systems in organizations, focusing on how technology enables business strategy and operations.

topics: Database Planning (Data Planning, Requirements Specification, Conceptual Design, Logical Design, Physical Design)
Chapter Objectives (Logical database design, Converting ER diagrams to relational tables, Need for data normalization)
E-R Model Entity and its attributes (Salesperson example, primary key)
Converting a Simple Entity (to a table)
Converting One-to-Many Relationship (Foreign key on the 'many' side)
Converting Many-to-Many Relationship (Three relational tables, intersection data/associative entity)
Normalization Forms (First, Second, and Third Normal Form examples)
Core Definition and Scope of a Product (Anything offered to a market to satisfy a want or need, including goods, services, and experiences)
Product Classification (Dividing products into Industrial and Consumer types based on purchase purpose)
Detailed Consumer Product Categories (Classification based on customer buying behavior: Convenience, Shopping, Specialty, and Unsought Products)
The Three Levels of Product (Modeling a product's value proposition across Core Customer Value, Actual Product Attributes, and Augmented Product Services)
Key Product Attributes (Defining Product Quality and its components like Performance Quality, Conformance Quality, Branding, and Packaging)
The Stages of the Product Life Cycle (PLC) (Analyzing sales, profit, costs, customers, and competitors across Introduction, Growth, Maturity, and Decline stages)
PLC Marketing Strategies (Outlining distinct strategies for Product, Price, Distribution, Advertising, and Sales Promotion for each PLC stage)
PLC Curve Variations (Examining non-standard life cycle patterns: Growth-Decline, Cycle-Recycle, Innovative/Scalloped, and the differences between Style, Fashion, and Fad)
The Ansoff Growth Matrix (Using the 2x2 matrix to identify corporate growth strategies: Market Penetration, Product Development, Market Development, and Diversification)

The Boston Consulting Group (BCG) Matrix (Using the 2x2 matrix of Market Growth Rate vs. Relative Market Share to classify products/SBUs as Stars, Cash Cows, Question Marks, and Dogs, and determining appropriate strategies)

reference_textbooks: Statistics for Business: Decision Making and Analysis by Robert E Stine and Dean Foster, Pearson (ISBN: 978-81-317-3347-9)
course_description: Regression models are among the most powerful statistical models used in business analysis. This course introduces students to the concepts of regression by modeling dependent behavior and relationships among variables, followed by analysis of covariance and logistic regression as a classifier. The objective is to help students identify relationships, use predictive models and analyze correlations.

topics: Use of categorical variables in regression models
